title: National Parks of Costa Rica
shortDescription: Volcanoes, rainforests and coastlines protected for future generations.
longDescription: Costa Rica is home to an extraordinary National System of Conservation Areas that protects an incredible diversity of ecosystems and unique species found nowhere else in the world. From majestic volcanoes like Arenal, Po√°s, Iraz√∫, and Rinc√≥n de la Vieja, to the mystical cloud forests of Monteverde and Santa Elena, the country is a true natural sanctuary. Its national parks, such as Manuel Antonio, Corcovado, Tortuguero, and Cahuita, shelter an astonishing variety of wildlife, including monkeys, jaguars, sloths, sea turtles, and exotic birds. Marine reserves like Marino Ballena and Coco Island protect coral reefs, mangroves, and endangered marine species. This extensive system not only promotes scientific research and environmental education but also drives sustainable ecotourism, encouraging the conservation of biodiversity and respect for natural resources.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: A 7,800-ha reserve in the Tilar√°n Mining Sierra preserving premontane wet forests. Elevation up to ~1,520 m; avg. temperature ~21¬∞C; rainfall ~3,461 mm. Over 50 species recorded as endemic to Costa Rica.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Declared in 1975 (Decree 4960-A). Category adjustments in 1991 and 1993. Co-managed by the University of Costa Rica (Western HQ) and SINAC.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Restricted access focused on research and education. Entry typically requires prior authorization; fees per SINAC decrees for research stays. Verify with SINAC/UCR before planning.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Rodolfo Ruiz Research Station (basic labs/classroom, kitchen, restrooms, bunk lodging), ranger posts at Cedral and Bajo Jamaical. Primary appeal is scientific research and biodiversity monitoring.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Research permits required under Biodiversity Law No. 7788. No extraction or introduction of species; follow biosecurity and low-impact guidelines. Coordinate logistics with SINAC and UCR in advance.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Iconic stratovolcano with conical profile, surrounded by rainforest trails and historic lava flows. Nearby hot springs and waterfalls complement the park experience.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Known for its 1968 eruption and subsequent activity phases; the park protects volcanic landscapes and mid-elevation forests important for hydrology and wildlife.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Typical hours 8:00‚Äì16:00; reference rates have historically differed for residents and non-residents. Verify current hours/rates and any sector-specific rules via SINAC‚Äôs booking portal.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Signed trails to viewpoints and old flows; basic services in main sectors; private hot springs and falls in the surrounding area (outside SINAC).

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Reserve high-demand slots in peak seasons; bring rain gear and sturdy footwear; respect volcanic risk signage.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: One of Costa Rica‚Äôs largest protected areas (~50,000 ha) spanning steep mountains blanketed by dense forest, carved by deep canyons and rivers crucial for hydroelectric production.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Established to conserve Caribbean-slope forests near the Central Volcanic Range and safeguard watershed services for the Greater Metropolitan Area.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Hours and fees vary by sector (e.g., Quebrada Gonz√°lez, Volc√°n Barva). Check current schedules and pricing with SINAC before visiting.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Sector-based trail systems, viewpoints, ranger stations; birding hotspots along the highway corridor; access points differ by sector.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Expect heavy rainfall and fog; drive carefully on mountain roads; verify which sector/trails are open prior to travel.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Protects white-sand beaches, coastal rainforest and one of the best-preserved coral reefs on Costa Rica‚Äôs Caribbean coast.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Created to conserve critical marine and coastal habitats, including reef, seagrass, and mangroves intertwined with Afro-Caribbean culture.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Hours can vary seasonally; snorkeling access is weather/visibility dependent. Verify with SINAC locally.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Beach trails, reef snorkeling with authorized operators, wildlife viewing (sloths, monkeys, iguanas).

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Use certified guides for reef activities; avoid stepping on coral; pack out all trash.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Unique transition forest between dry and wet Pacific zones, yielding exceptional biodiversity and reliable sightings of scarlet macaws.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Protected to conserve lowland Pacific habitats and key wildlife corridors near the T√°rcoles River.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Sector hours and accessibility features vary; confirm details on the SINAC page before travel.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Universal-access trails, birding platforms, proximity to crocodile view points along the T√°rcoles bridge (outside park limits).

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Go early for bird activity; respect wildlife distance; high humidity year-round.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Home to Cerro Chirrip√≥ (3,821 m), with p√°ramo ecosystems, glacial lakes, and sweeping views on clear mornings.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Created to protect high-elevation habitats unique in Central America; access is quota-controlled to reduce impact.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Entrance and lodging require advance booking through authorized systems; verify current rates and quotas with SINAC.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Long-distance hiking to base camps, lakes, and summits; basic services in refuges via concessionaires (subject to change).

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Train adequately, pack for cold/wet conditions, and book well in advance.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Often described as one of the most biologically intense places on Earth. Five visitor sectors: San Pedrillo, Sirena, La Leona, Los Patos, and El Tigre.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Protected to conserve the last large tracts of Pacific lowland rainforest in Central America; strict regulations due to sensitive wildlife and terrain.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Open daily 7:00‚Äì16:00. Sirena sector closes to visitors in October. Reference rates: residents ¬¢1,600; non-residents US$15; separate camping fees in designated stations; child rates available. Verify per sector and season.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Ranger stations, guided trails, wildlife viewing (tapirs, macaws, monkeys, cats). Many itineraries require certified guides and prior reservations.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Book certified guides; carry sufficient water/food; expect hot, humid conditions; check river/sea conditions for access.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Important for protecting water resources for Grecia, Po√°s, and Valverde Vega; mix of secondary forest, plantations, and recreation areas.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Established as a forest reserve with local community value for education and watershed protection.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Managed access with day-use areas; verify up-to-date schedule and fees locally.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Short trails, picnic sites, lookout points; environmental education activities.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Weekends can be busy; pack out trash and respect watershed rules.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Costa Rica‚Äôs largest pre-Columbian archaeological site set within protected forest, featuring stone mounds, causeways, aqueducts, and petroglyphs.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Monument preserves an advanced pre-Hispanic settlement and hydraulic engineering; ongoing research and conservation.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Day-use; confirm current hours and prices via SINAC and local sector office.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Interpretive trails, museum/visitor center (as available), guided visits.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Wear sturdy shoes; respect cultural heritage‚Äîno climbing on structures.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Costa Rica‚Äôs highest volcano, with multiple craters and lunar landscapes; close to San Jos√© with paved road access.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Repeated eruptive phases shaped today‚Äôs craters; park created to conserve high-elevation habitats and geological features.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: SINAC lists dedicated sections for hours and fees; verify before travel due to weather and capacity controls.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Lookouts, signed paths near crater rims, ranger presence, parking; conditions can be windy and cold.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Arrive early for clearer views; bring warm layers and sun protection; monitor volcanic advisories.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Mountainous landscapes and panoramic viewpoints named after a local legend that the massif resembles a crab.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Protected to conserve Pacific slope forests and watersheds west of the Central Valley.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Typical hours 8:00‚Äì16:00; verify seasonal updates and entrance fees with SINAC.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Summit/lookout hikes, birding along mid-elevation forests; basic sector services.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Carry water and sun protection; some trails are steep and exposed.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: High-elevation cloud forests protecting habitat for the resplendent quetzal and other montane species.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Created to safeguard critical breeding and feeding areas along the Talamanca highlands.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Commonly open in daytime hours; fees differ for residents/non-residents. Verify with SINAC.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Birdwatching trails, viewpoints, ranger posts; chilly, humid conditions.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Best sightings at dawn; hire local bird guides; dress in layers.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Compact park with stunning beaches and dense wildlife (monkeys, sloths, toucans) connected by a well-maintained trail network.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Protected to conserve lowland Pacific coastal habitats amid tourism pressure; ongoing management balances access and conservation.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Open Wednesday‚ÄìMonday (closed Tuesdays); capacity controls apply. Tickets are sold exclusively online via SINAC‚Äîcreate an account and book in advance.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Marked trails to Playa Espadilla Sur, Playa Manuel Antonio, and viewpoints; restrooms and ranger facilities in main sector.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Book early in high season; no single-use plastics; secure food‚Äîmonkeys and raccoons are habituated to visitors.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Marine and coastal park famous for seasonal humpback whale migrations and the ‚Äòwhale tail‚Äô tombolo at Playa Uvita.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Created to protect coral reefs, seagrass, mangroves, and coastal fauna on the southern Pacific coast.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Daytime hours with tide-dependent access to the ‚Äòwhale tail.‚Äô Fees posted by SINAC; confirm locally.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Boat tours for whales/dolphins in season, snorkeling on suitable conditions, beaches and coastal walks.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Check tides; use certified operators; respect marine wildlife distances.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Hosts one of the world‚Äôs largest active craters amid cloud forest. Access may be restricted due to volcanic conditions.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Long history of eruptions shaped current crater lakes and fumaroles; monitoring informs visitor management.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Timed entries and mandatory online reservations may apply; verify on SINAC before travel.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Lookouts near the main crater, visitor information, short interpretive trails; closures possible during activity spikes.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Arrive early for visibility; follow safety instructions; bring jackets and eye protection if windy.

items.title: Rinc√≥n de la Vieja National Park

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Active volcanic complex with mud pots, fumaroles, and diverse ecosystems from dry to cloud forest across multiple sectors.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Protected to conserve volcanic landscapes and Guanacaste dry forests; management varies by sector and season.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Common hours by sector include 7:00‚Äì15:00 or 8:00‚Äì16:00; residents/non-residents rates differ. Verify current sector access.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Sector Pailas mud pots and short loops; longer hikes to waterfalls and viewpoints; ranger stations and basic facilities.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: High temps and sun exposure‚Äîcarry water and hat; heed volcanic advisories; some trails close during rainy season.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Part of the Guanacaste Conservation Area; protects seasonal dry forests, wildlife, surf beaches, and the historic 1856 battle site.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Established both for biodiversity and national heritage conservation; later recognized as part of a UNESCO World Heritage complex.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Daytime hours; fees posted by SINAC. Some sectors require coordination; verify before visiting.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Historic hacienda area, beaches (seasonal turtle nesting), wildlife viewing, trails and lookouts.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Dry season is very hot; bring water and sun protection; respect nesting beach protocols.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Protects the turquoise R√≠o Celeste created by mineral mixing at ‚ÄòTe√±ideros‚Äô, plus rainforest and volcanic features.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Park established to conserve the Tenorio volcanic massif and iconic Celeste watershed under growing visitation.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Entry daily 8:00‚Äì14:00; exit allowed until 16:00. Reference rates: residents ¬¢800; non-residents US$12. Always verify current pricing and capacity.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Signed trail to the 30-m R√≠o Celeste waterfall, viewpoints, ranger facilities, drinking water, restrooms, parking.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Arrive early; trail can be muddy‚Äîuse proper footwear; swimming usually prohibited in protected sections.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Remote Caribbean-slope park accessible only by boat or plane, famous for nesting sea turtles, extensive canals, and mangroves.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Established to protect critical turtle nesting beaches and vast lowland wetlands on the northern Caribbean coast.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: SINAC provides sector-specific hours/fees. Book boats/guides in Tortuguero village; verify seasonal rules for nesting access.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Canal boat tours, guided night turtle walks in season, observation towers, ranger posts.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Respect turtle-watching protocols (no flash, certified guides). Heavy rains common‚Äîpack waterproof layers.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Easternmost stratovolcano of the Central Volcanic Range with three craters; landscapes shaped by explosive and effusive events.

sections.heading: History
sections.content: Periodic eruptive phases have prompted adaptive visitor management, including area closures when necessary.

sections.heading: Hours and Rates
sections.content: Access depends on volcanic activity and sector status; confirm current openings, hours and fees with SINAC before travel.

sections.heading: Services and Attractions
sections.content: Lookouts and trails when open; dramatic highland scenery; basic services in open sectors.

sections.heading: Recommendations
sections.content: Check seismic/volcanic advisories; bring warm layers; follow ranger guidance strictly.
